photo.description: Hearst Castle, at San Simeon, is a vast folly created by William Randolph Hearst. He rampaged through Europe collecting art, pieces of buildings and whatever else people would sell him. He was the inspiratio for Citizen Kane.
photo.title: Hearst Castle

photo.description: Hearst Castle, at San Simeon, is a vast folly created by William Randolph Hearst. He rampaged through Europe collecting art, pieces of buildings and whatever else people would sell him. He was the inspiration for Citizen Kane. This is the front door.

photo.title: Hearst Castle

photo.description: Hearst Castle is a National and California Historical Landmark mansion located on the Central Coast of California, United States. It was designed by architect Julia Morgan between 1919 and 1947 for newspaper magnate William Randolph Hearst, who died in 1951. In 1957, the Hearst Corporation donated the property to the state of California. Since that time it has been maintained as a state historic park where the estate, and its considerable collection of art and antiques, is open for public tours. Despite its location far from any urban center, the site attracts about one million visitors per year. photo.description: Hearst Castle, at San Simeon, is a vast folly created by William Randolph Hearst. He rampaged through Europe collecting art, pieces of buildings and whatever else people would sell him. He was the inspiration for Citizen Kane. Furriners can be recognised by their fondness for squirrels. But I was promised zebras.

photo.description: One of the tour guides saw me grabbing a shot of this stuffed owl in the Billiard Room. He pulled me aside and told me a great story about how it came to be. It involved a teenage son, a new rifle, and a lesson. William Randolph Hearst cared for animals.
photo.title: Hearst Castle - Stuffed Owl

photo.description: Hearst Castle, San Simeon, CA Jun '07 Neptune pool is 104 feet long, 58 feet wide and 95 feet wide at alcove. It is 3.5 feet deep at the west end, 10 feet at drains and holds 345,000 gallons of water. Other unique aspects of the Neptune Pool include the oil burning heating system, the light-veined Vermont marble decorating the pools and colonnades, and four 17-century Italian bas-reliefs on the sides of the colonnades.
photo.tags: ca castle pool sansimeon hearstcastle neptunepool ca1 fovea heasrtcastle centralis foveacentralis
photo.title: Neptune pool & the semi-circular colannades

photo.description: Although we were told by one of the volunteers at Hearst Castle that there names are Charm, Bloom, and Joy, I have discovered that &quot;Although the Graces usually numbered three, according to the Spartans, Cleta, not Thalia, was the third, and other Graces are sometimes mentioned, including Auxo, Charis, Hegemone, Phaenna, and Pasithea. An ancient vase painting attests the following names: Antheia, Eudaimonia, Paidia, Pandaisia, Pannychis - all referring to the Charites as patronesses of amusement and festivities.&quot; (http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiCharites)
photo.tags: california ca castle art naked nude artwork statues sansimeon hearstcastle marble hearst alabaster 18200mm
photo.title: IMG_4498 Backside Of 3 Graces

photo.title: From Zebras to Rosemary

photo.description: We were told their names are Charm, Bloom, and Joy - we since found out that is not at all accurate. However, there are many different interpretations or representations of the various Greek and Roman myths by various scholars, artist, and poets. *One may say they are the goddesses of charm, beauty, nature, human creativity and fertility. From youngest to oldest: Aglaea (&quot;Splendor&quot;), Euphrosyne (&quot;Mirth&quot;), and Thalia (&quot;Good Cheer&quot;). Or they may be Cleta rather than Thalia, or any of Auxo, Charis, Hegemone, Phaenna, or Pasithea. Or any three out of Antheia, Eudaimonia, Paidia, Pandaisia, Pannychis - all referring to the Charites as patronesses of amusement and festivities. Charisma, Persuasion, Sleep and Grace are also said to be of the Graces. *per my interpretation of the Wikipedia article of the Charities as they relate to the Graces.
photo.tags: california ca girls castle art nature beauty naked nude greek amusement artwork roman sleep joy statues charm grace mirth bloom wikipedia sansimeon hearstcastle marble fertility festivities hearst goddesses thalia graces charis charisma splendor persuasion alabaster paidia euphrosyne 18200mm charities cleta goodcheer charites antheia eudaimonia aglaea humancreativity pasithea hegemone patronesses auxo pannychis phaenna pandaisia
photo.title: IMG_4502 Three Naked Girls

photo.description: The three girls, Grace, Cleta and Phaenna. We were told their names are Charm, Bloom, and Joy - we since found out that is not at all accurate. However, there are many different interpretations or representations of the various Greek and Roman myths by various scholars, artist, and poets. *One may say they are the goddesses of charm, beauty, nature, human creativity and fertility. From youngest to oldest: Aglaea (&quot;Splendor&quot;), Euphrosyne (&quot;Mirth&quot;), and Thalia (&quot;Good Cheer&quot;). Or they may be Cleta rather than Thalia, or any of Auxo, Charis, Hegemone, Phaenna, or Pasithea. Or any three out of Antheia, Eudaimonia, Paidia, Pandaisia, Pannychis - all referring to the Charites as patronesses of amusement and festivities. Charisma, Persuasion, Sleep and Grace are also said to be of the Graces. *per my interpretation of the Wikipedia article of the Charities as they relate to the Graces.

photo.title: IMG_4501 The Three Graces

From youngest to oldest: Aglaea (&quot;Splendor&quot;), Euphrosyne (&quot;Mirth&quot;), and Thalia (&quot;Good Cheer&quot;). Or they may be Cleta rather than Thalia, or any of Auxo, Charis, Hegemone, Phaenna, or Pasithea.
